summary: This document is an email chain from April 2023 between FBI agents discussing an urgent deconfliction request from FinCEN regarding the release of Suspicious Activity Reports (SARs) related to Jeffrey Epstein. The SARs are sought for civil lawsuits against JPMorgan Chase and Deutsche Bank. The FBI is asked to review a list of names from their investigation to object or not to their release.

persons.name: Ghislaine Maxwell
persons.context: Mentioned as a reason for the USAO not releasing information due to a pending appeal in her case.

persons.name: Jeffrey Epstein
persons.role: Sex offender, subject of financial investigations
persons.context: Central figure in the civil lawsuits against banks for providing financial services to him; his financial transactions are the subject of the SARs under discussion.

persons.name: Robert Trivers
persons.context: Listed among 10 additional names provided by FinCEN for the FBI to review and potentially object to their information being released in SARs.

persons.name: Seamus
persons.context: Addressed in an email regarding the deconfliction request and the list of names from FinCEN.

connections.description: Maxwell is directly associated with Epstein's case, as her pending appeal is cited as a reason for withholding information.
Trivers is one of several individuals whose names appear in SARs related to Epstein's financial transactions, suggesting a financial connection under investigation.

events.title: FinCEN Deconfliction Request Initiated
events.description: The FBI receives an urgent request from FinCEN to review names from investigation NY-3027571 and object, if necessary, to the release of SARs related to Jeffrey Epstein in ongoing civil litigation.

events.title: FBI Confirms No Objection to Release
events.description: An FBI Supervisory Special Agent confirms there is no objection to releasing information, including that mentioning Ghislaine Maxwell, in response to FinCEN's deconfliction request.

events.title: Civil Lawsuits Against Banks Filed
events.description: Civil lawsuits are filed in SDNY against JPMorgan Chase and Deutsche Bank by an unnamed Epstein victim (and a class) and separately by the US Virgin Islands, alleging the banks provided financial services to sex offender Jeffrey Epstein.

locations: Federal District Court for the Southern District of New York (SDNY)
keyFacts: FinCEN sought FBI deconfliction to release Suspicious Activity Reports (SARs) related to Jeffrey Epstein's financial transactions for use in civil lawsuits against JPMorgan Chase and Deutsche Bank.
The USAO had been withholding information due to a pending appeal in the Ghislaine Maxwell case, but the FBI indicated no objection to the release.
The civil litigation involves an unnamed Epstein victim (and a class) suing the banks, and a separate suit by the U.S. Virgin Islands government against JPMorgan.
A list of names, including Robert Trivers, was provided by FinCEN for the FBI to review for potential objections to their information being disclosed.
The presiding judge indicated he might order the disclosure of the SARs if FinCEN did not authorize it, creating urgency for the deconfliction request.
